lexUnit.name: savour.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: appreciate and enjoy the taste of (good food or drink)

sentence.text: She drank , savouring the flavour with closed eyes .
Savour the flavour of salmon with this super stainless steel fish kettle .
Try to eat slowly and really savour your food at meals so that you feel satisfied and therefore less likely to snack later on .
He concentrated on the figure , held it in his mind , savouring it as a wine expert savours a fine vintage .
Guido took a mouthful of his Cynar and seemed to savour it for a moment .
He sat back in his tattered armchair and savoured his drink for a moment .
They sat savouring the malty brew for a while with the darkness silent outside the windows .
The greatest joy was to make camp for the night and savour the smell from the cooks ' fires as supper was prepared .
He tapped the ash off his thick Havana cigar and savoured the large cognac before returning to his guest .
Harry reached around her and carefully , even tenderly , plucked the bloom , savouring its fragrance before handing it to Katherine .
He swirled the caramel liquor around in his cupped palm and savoured its bouquet before taking another small taste .
He leaned back , savouring the cigar , letting the smoke drift slowly from between his slightly parted lips .
She swigged a mouthful of wine with relish , irrigating her tongue to savour the bitter fruitiness .
He rolls the word around his mouth , as if savouring a good malt .
` The pain will be exquisite , Doctor , and I shall savour every nuance of your screams .
It was a treat to be savoured …
Dinner is an occasion to be savoured with candlelight , cut glass and fine china .
He stripped off his coat and her fingers splayed across his back , savouring the warmth of his skin through his shirt .
Take time to savour a wine 's qualities and make notes , so you can remember its name .
These are days to savour .
` I ca n't say that the experience was one to savour . "
